data.description: The Appalachian Trail is a 2,180+ mile long public footpath that traverses the scenic, wooded, pastoral, wild, and culturally resonant lands of the Appalachian Mountains. Conceived in 1921, built by private citizens, and completed in 1937, today the trail is managed by the National Park Service, US Forest Service, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, numerous state agencies and thousands of volunteers.

entranceFees.description: The Appalachian National Scenic Trail (NST) does not charge an entrance fee for use of the trail on Appalachian NST land.
entranceFees.title: Appalachian National Scenic Trail Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: There are many points of access along the Appalachian Trail, whether it is by car, train, bus or plane. For more detailed directions, please refer to the "Directions" section of our park webpage.

operatingHours.description:
In general, the Appalachian Trail is open year-round. The northern terminus at Mount Katahdin in Maine is within Baxter State Park, which may be closed in winter months, depending on weather conditions. 
Particular sections of the Trail, and less-developed roads accessing the Trail, may be closed temporarily for a number of reasons, but otherwise the trail is open.
operatingHours.name: Appalachian National Scenic Trail

images.title: McAfee Knob
images.altText: Silhouette of a man with backpack standing on McAfee Knob at sunset with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: McAfee Knob is one of the most popular locations along the A.T. to take photographs.

images.title: Appalachian Trail
images.altText: The Appalachian Trail runs across a mountain ridge line with views to the horizon of mountain range.
images.caption: Crossing into thirteen states, hikers experience a variety of scenery along the way.

images.title: The Infamous White Blaze of the A.T.
images.altText: A white blaze marks a tree in the foreground, with a man and child walking away on the wooded trail.
images.caption: The white blaze marks the Appalachian Trail as a way for hikers to identify the route.

images.credit: Photo Credit: Maine Appalachian Trail Club
images.title: Volunteer on the A.T.
images.altText: A volunteer is carrying a split log while walking across a wooden footbridge in the woods.
images.caption: The Appalachian Trail is maintained largely by volunteers.

images.title: Winter on the A.T.
images.altText: A snowy winter view from the A.T. overlooking snowy mountains and clouds in the distance.
images.caption: Hikers can experience many seasons along the A.T. all year round. It is important to be prepared.

data.weatherInfo: It is your responsibility to be prepared for all weather conditions, including extreme and unexpected weather changes year-round. As the trail runs from Georgia to Maine there will be different weather conditions depending on your location. For weather along specific sections of the trail and at specific shelters, please refer to: http://www.atweather.org/
data.name: Appalachian

data.description: A Blue Ridge Parkway experience is unlike any other: a slow-paced and relaxing drive revealing stunning long-range vistas and close-up views of the rugged mountains and pastoral landscapes of the Appalachian Highlands. The Parkway meanders for 469 miles, protecting a diversity of plants and animals, and providing opportunities for enjoying all that makes this region of the country so special.
data.directionsInfo: The parkway is a 469-mile-long scenic road connecting Shenandoah National Park in Virginia to Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina. Numerous federal and state highways provide access to the parkway. Milepost markers are positioned every mile along the parkway, starting at 0 in Virginia and ending at 469 in North Carolina. We suggest using a map to identify the area you want to visit, as GPS directions often do not incorporate the parkway's milepost system.

operatingHours.description:
The road is open 24 hours a day, weather permitting. Road closures due to inclement weather occur most frequently during winter. Sections of the road may also be closed during road maintenance projects. Check our road closure map to verify that the parkway is open before traveling.

Visitor centers and other facilities have hours and seasons that vary. Most picnic areas, campgrounds, and visitor centers are closed from the beginning of November until early May.
operatingHours.name: Parkway Road Hours

images.title: Evening on the Blue Ridge
images.altText: A long pine tree stands in front of distant mountain ridges beneath an orange sunset
images.caption: Evening on the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.title: Mountain vista
images.altText: Mountain vista and clouds on the Blue Ridge Parkway
images.caption: Beautiful mountain in North Carolina draw visitors from around the world to the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.title: Sunset from Cowee Mountain Overlook
images.altText: Storm clouds breaking over the mountains at sunset, with fog hugging the valleys
images.caption: Sunset from Cowee Mountain Overlook

images.title: Linn Cove Viaduct
images.altText: A roadway on piers follows the curve of a mountainside, running toward distant mountains.
images.caption: Linn Cove Viaduct is one of the most iconic features of the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.title: Black Bear
images.altText: Black Bear sitting on large rocks at the edge of a forest
images.caption: Black bears are among the many mammals found across the Blue Ridge Parkway.

images.title: Mabry Mill
images.altText: Summer colors at Mabry Mill
images.caption: Located in Virginia's Plateau district, picturesque Mabry Mill is one of the most iconic features of the Blue Ridge Parkway

images.title: Linville Falls
images.altText: water cascading into Linville Falls plunge basin
images.caption: The Linville Gorge offers visitors the opportunity to learn about fascinating geology and view magnificent waterfalls.

data.weatherInfo: The weather on the parkway can vary widely along its 469-mile route. Precipitation is possible any time of the year. Winter can be cold and snowy, especially at the higher elevations. Spring and fall can have large temperature swings, from near freezing to over 80 degrees Fahrenheit. Summers are hot in the lower elevations, but the highest elevations remain cooler. Summertime thunderstorms are common, so be prepared for weather changes.
data.name: Blue Ridge

data.description: The sound of ocean waves, the starry night sky, or the calm of the salt marshes, you can experience it all. Shaped by the forces of water, wind, and storms these islands are ever changing. The plants, wildlife, and people who live here adapt continually. Whether you are enjoying the beach, kayaking the sound, or climbing the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse there is something for everyone to explore!

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enjoy the grounds of Cape Hatteras National Seashore.
entranceFees.title: Park Entrance

data.directionsInfo: Cape Hatteras National Seashore is located along NC-12 in the Outer Banks of North Carolina. You can reach the seashore from the north by following US 158 to Nag Heads, NC and the turn-off to NC-12 and Cape Hatteras National Seashore. From the south, you can take NCDOT ferries from Swanquarter, NC and Cedar Island, NC to the village of Ocracoke on Ocracoke Island. The provided physical address is the location of the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse, roughly in the middle of the park.

operatingHours.description: The grounds of Cape Hatteras National Seashore are always open for visitors, though there are resource closures that seasonally affect different parts of the beach.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: Fresnel Lens
images.altText: The first-order Fresnel lens is visible in the lantern room of the Bodie Island Lighthouse.
images.caption: Bodie Island Lighthouse still has its first-order Fresnel lens.

images.title: Paddling Pamlico Sound
images.altText: A young girl paddles across the water with the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse visible in the distance.
images.caption: Lots of recreation opportunities await visits on the sound side of the barrier islands.

images.title: Cape Hatteras Lighthouse
images.altText: Black and white painting of the brick Cape Hatteras Lighthouse.
images.caption: Black and white spirals decorate the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse.

images.title: Playing in the Sand
images.altText: Two kids play in the sand.
images.caption: Two kids enjoy the sands of Cape Hatteras.

data.weatherInfo: The weather along the Outer Banks varies throughout the year and even throughout the day. Please check the National Weather Service information at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for forecast information.
data.name: Cape Hatteras

data.description: A boat ride three miles off-shore brings you to the barrier islands of Cape Lookout National Seashore. Horse watching, shelling, fishing, birding, camping, lighthouse climbing, and touring historic villages--there’s something for everyone at Cape Lookout. Be sure to bring all the food, water, and supplies you need (and carry your trash out of the park) when visiting these remote beaches.

entranceFees.description: There is no charge for coming to Cape Lookout National Seashore.  The Harkers Island Visitor Center and the Beaufort Visitor Information Center can be reached by car.  All other locations require a trip by ferry.  There is a charge for the ferry. Contact the ferry company for costs and schedules.
entranceFees.title: Cape Lookout Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: Only two areas of Cape Lookout National Seashore can be reached without taking a ferry: the Visitor Center on Harkers Island and the Visitor Information Center in Beaufort, NC. Please note: the park mailing address does not bring you to the Harkers Island Visitor Center parking lot. If you are using a GPS device - use the parking lot coordinates (34.68494, -74.52725) or the following "address" which approximates the location of the parking lot entrance: 1800 Island Rd, Harkers Island, NC 28531

operatingHours.description: Cape Lookout National Seashore is open 24 hours and 365 days a year (weather permitting). Operating hours for visitor centers and other services will vary throughout the year.
operatingHours.name: Cape Lookout National Seashore

images.title: Cape Lookout Lighthouse
images.altText: : Black & white patterned tower of the Cape Lookout Lighthouse stands against a blue & white cloud f
images.caption: The Cape Lookout Lighthouse is still an active aid-to-navigation, warning ships of the nearby shoals.  Climbing to up to see the view from the gallery level, 14 stories above the ground, is also a popular activity by visitors during the summer.

images.title: Sea Oats
images.altText: Mature sea oat plant seed heads gracefully drooping in the sun
images.caption: In late summer, Sea Oats are the most conspicuous plant growing on the sand dunes with their graceful, drooping seed heads.

images.title: Sanderlings
images.altText: small sandpipers poke their bills in the sand while waves break in the background
images.caption: Small sandpipers, called Sanderlings, are common sights on the ocean beach as they search for food in the sand between waves

images.title: Relaxing by the Ocean
images.altText: 2 ladies sit in beach chairs on the sand with their feet in the water
images.caption: Watching the waves, feeling the cool sea breeze and the warmth of the sun make for a relaxing day.

images.title: Surf fishing
images.altText: A surf fisherman stands in the water holding his surf rod and watching the waves
images.caption: Surf fishing is a popular pastime at the beach

data.weatherInfo: Spring: Temperatures generally range from 50 F to 70+ F. Rain & wind are common Summer: Temperatures usually range from 80 F to 100 F with high humidity (80-90%). Average wind speed is 10-15 mph. Be prepared with plenty of water. With little shade on the islands, an umbrella to provide shade from the sun is a good idea. Fall: Temperatures usually range from the high 70 F to the upper 40 F. Winter: Temperatures usually range from 50 F - 32 F. Winds can be strong. Dress in layers.
data.name: Cape Lookout

data.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
data.description: “I make it clear why I write as I do and why other poets write as they do. After hundreds of experiments I decided to go my own way in style and see what would happen.” Carl Sandburg's free verse style of poetry, journalism, biography, children's stories, prose writing, and social activism provided a popular voice for the American people of the twentieth century.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter the park to hike the trails, enjoy the grounds or visit the barn and bookstore.  Start your visit in the ground floor of the Sandburg Home for information, house tour tickets, videos and more.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description:
Online house tour reservations available at https://www.recreation.gov/ticket/facility/300005
Tours free until further notice ($1/ticket service fee for online reservations.)
entranceFees.title: House Tour Fee - Adults age 16-61

entranceFees.description:
Online house tour reservations available at https://www.recreation.gov/ticket/facility/300005
Tours free until further notice ($1/ticket service fee for online reservations.)
entranceFees.title: House Tour Fee - Adults age 62 and older, and all interagency pass holders

entranceFees.description:
Online house tour reservations available at https://www.recreation.gov/ticket/facility/300005.
Child reservations online will incur $1.00 processing fee.  Day-of-tour walk up child tickets are free.
entranceFees.title: House Tour Fee - Children age 15 and under

data.directionsInfo: The park is located three miles south of Hendersonville, NC on Little River Road off of the Greenville Highway/Rt. 225 in Flat Rock, NC. Visitors using GPS or mapping software should use 1800 Little River Road and look for the signs directing you to the main visitor parking lot off Little River Road. To access the Hikers Parking lot, use 81 Carl Sandburg Lane as the GPS address. You will see signs for the Hiker's parking lot, on the left, just before Carl Sandburg Lane.

operatingHours.description:
Parking lots, grounds, gardens, and trails are open every day, year-round, sunrise to sunset. Occasional closures arise from weather events, check park alerts for more information.

The Sandburg Home, Visitor Center and Farm Area have seasonal hours that vary.
operatingHours.name: PARK HOURS

images.altText: A view of the Sandburg Home as visitors enter the park
images.caption: The Sandburg family enjoyed living in the Carolina mountains along with a collection of 12,000 books and a herd of dairy goats.

data.description: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site protects and preserves known portions of England's first New World settlements from 1584 to 1590. This site also preserves the cultural heritage of the Native Americans, European Americans and African Americans who have lived on Roanoke Island.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee collected at Fort Raleigh National Historic Site.
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

data.directionsInfo: Fort Raleigh National Historic Site is located on the northern end of Roanoke Island, north of the town of Manteo, NC.

operatingHours.description: The grounds are open for visitation 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

images.title: First Light of Freedom
images.altText: Back of the monument commemorating the Roanoke Island Freedmen's Colony
images.caption: Commemorating the Roanoke Island Freedmen's Colony

images.title: Thomas Hariot Trail
images.altText: Tree standing next to the maritime forest path of the Thomas Hariot Trail
images.caption: Venture through a maritime forest

images.title: Crucible Artifact
images.altText: Pieces of a crucible left behind by the 1585 English expedition
images.caption: Shards unearthed here provide clues to the English expedition of 1585

images.title: Waterside Theatre
images.altText: Stage of the Waterside Theatre with a view of the Roanoke Sound in the background
images.caption: Home of The Lost Colony drama performed every summer

data.weatherInfo: Weather on the Outer Banks varies seasonally and daily. Please check the National Weather Service at http://www.weather.gov/mhx/ for up-to-date weather forecast information.
data.name: Fort Raleigh

data.description: Ridge upon ridge of forest straddles the border between North Carolina and Tennessee in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. World renowned for its diversity of plant and animal life, the beauty of its ancient mountains, and the quality of its remnants of Southern Appalachian mountain culture, this is America's most visited national park. Plan your visit today!
data.directionsInfo: Great Smoky Mountains National Park straddles the borders of the states of Tennessee and North Carolina. The three main entrances to the park are in Gatlinburg, TN; Townsend, TN; and Cherokee, NC.

operatingHours.description: Primary roads are open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, year-round, weather permitting. This includes Newfound Gap Road (US-441), Little River Road, and Laurel Creek Road. Secondary roads are closed seasonally.
operatingHours.name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park

images.title: The "Wildflower National Park"
images.altText: A hillside in the forest covered with white trillium flowers
images.caption: Wildflowers, such as these white trillium, can be found blooming from February through November in the park.

images.title: Fall Colors Near Newfound Gap
images.altText: Bright gold and red leaves shine through the fog in a forest.
images.caption: Fall leaf season is one of the busiest times of year in the park.

images.title: Frosty Morning in Cades Cove
images.altText: A thick layer of frost covers the fields, trees, and mountains in Cades Cove.
images.caption: Wintertime brings a quiet beauty to the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.title: Fall Meets Winter
images.altText: Gold and red fall colors fill the valleys while snow coats the mountain tops.
images.caption: In spring and fall, weather in the foothills can be pleasant, while snow and cold rule on the mountain tops.

images.title: A Foggy Morning at Cades Cove Methodist Church
images.altText: Tombstones stand in front of a white, wooden church on a foggy morning.
images.caption: Historic buildings such as churches, gristmills, barns, and homes allow visitors to get a feel for life in the mountains before the national park was created.

images.title: The Waters of Roaring Fork Below Grotto Falls
images.altText: Rhododendron bushes line the banks of a stream filled with large boulders.
images.caption: Abundant rainfall means lush forests and beautiful stream scenes in the Great Smoky Mountains.

images.title: "Smoke" Rising From the Mountains
images.altText: Wisps of fog hang over the forests in the mountains.
images.caption: The park gets its name from mists that often rise like smoke from the mountains.

data.weatherInfo: Elevations in the park range from approximately 875 feet to 6,643 feet and the topography can drastically affect local weather. Temperatures can vary by 10-20 degrees Fahrenheit from mountain base to top, and clear skies lower down do not guarantee equally pleasant weather at higher elevations.
data.name: Great Smoky Mountains

data.description: "I never saw such fighting since God made me. The Americans fought like demons." - Lt. General Charles, Earl Cornwallis On March 15, 1781, six years into the American Revolution, General Greene and Lord Cornwallis' troops faced off at a small courthouse community. This 2.5 hour battle would change the course of the Southern Campaign of the American Revolution.

emailAddresses.description: This email is the basic contact that will then be routed by the Administration to the appropriate staff member.

entrancePasses.description:
Guilford Courthouse is a Fee-Free site, meaning you can enjoy the park for free!

The park sells Interagency Park Passes in the Battlefield Visitors Center.
entrancePasses.title: No Pass Required

data.directionsInfo: Guilford Courthouse National Military Park is located along US 220 and New Garden Road. To reach the Visitor Center, drive East on New Garden Road and turn right into the parking lot when you see the stone sign “Guilford Courthouse National Military Park.” If you drive down Old Battleground Road, do not drive through the Forest Lawn cemetery, this is a dead end and is not connected to the National Park. If you drive on Old Battleground, turn left onto New Garden Road Lat / Long: 36.1316499 / -79.8471879

operatingHours.description:
Start your visit at the Battlefield Visitor Center, located at 2332 New Garden Road, Greensboro NC 27410. The Visitors Center is open Wednesday through Sunday from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. These facilities close to visitors and motor vehicle traffic on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Years Day. 

The park is accessible by foot, and visitors are welcome to walk the trails until dusk.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.title: General Nathanael Greene Monument
images.altText: Bronze and granite monument of General Nathanael Greene on horseback
images.caption: The General Greene Monument is a focal point of commemoration on the battlefield

images.title: Hoskins' House and Kitchen
images.altText: Hoskins' House and Kitchen Located on the Grounds of the Colonial Heritage Center
images.caption: Hoskins' House and Kitchen Located on the Grounds of the Colonial Heritage Center

images.title: Historic New Garden Road
images.altText: A gravel path winds through a forest
images.caption: The Historic New Garden Road was a colonial highway and the location of the artillery during the Battle of Guilford Courthouse

images.title: 6 pounder cannons
images.altText: Two cannons on grey carriages (wheels) sit in a forest
images.caption: Anthony Singleton used two 6 pounder cannons like these reproductions at the American Third Line, the final battle point

images.title: 18th Century Field Drum
images.altText: 18th Century Field Drum at Guilford Courthouse National Military Park
images.caption: 18th Century Field Drum at Guilford Courthouse National Military Park

data.weatherInfo: https://www.nps.gov/guco/planyourvisit/weather.htm Summers are warm to hot and humid with the occasional thunderstorm. Spring and Fall are cool with rainy periods. Winter is mild and cold with snow and ice possible in January and February. Wear comfortable clothing for the season and good walking shoes year round!
data.name: Guilford Courthouse

data.description: In the early morning hours of February 27, 1776, Loyalist forces charged across a partially dismantled Moores Creek Bridge. Beyond the bridge, nearly 1,000 North Carolina Patriots waited quietly with cannons and muskets poised to fire. This battle marked the last broadsword charge by Scottish Highlanders and the first significant victory for the Patriots in the American Revolution.

emailAddresses.description: Get all your information needs here by sending a message to this Email.

data.directionsInfo: Moores Creek National Battlefield is located 20 miles NW of Wilmington, North Carolina. · From Highway 17, follow US 421 to NC 210, then West on NC 210 · From Interstate 40, take exit 408 (NC 210) West at Rocky Point. · From Interstate 95 North, take exit 13-A for NC 74 East towards Wilmington. · From Interstate 95 South: take exit 81-B for I-40 East towards Wilmington. · From Fayetteville, North Carolina, take Interstate 95 South to Exit 13-A Questions please call us as 910-283-5591 x2234

operatingHours.description:
Moores Creek National Battlefield is open daily from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm. Areas of access include the History and Tar Heel trails, Earthworks and Battlefield, and Widow Moores Creek Bridge. Additionally, access to picnic areas and the creek are available during these hours.

Moores Creek National Battlefield is closed on all Federal Holidays.
operatingHours.name: Park Trail Access Hours

operatingHours.description: The Visitor Center is open Tuesday - Saturday, 9:00 am to 5:00 pm. This includes access to exhibits, the park's 10-minute film, "In the Most Furious Manner", the gift shop and America the Beautiful passes.  Moores Creek National Battlefield is closed on all Federal Holidays. The Visitor Center Phone Number is 910-283-5591 ex.2234
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center

data.description: Stretching 330 miles through four states (Virginia, Tennessee, North and South Carolina) the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail traces the route used by patriot militia during the pivotal Kings Mountain campaign of 1780. Follow the campaign by utilizing a Commemorative Motor Route which uses existing state highways marked with the distinctive trail logo, or 87 miles of walkable pathways.
data.directionsInfo: The trail travels over 330 miles through four states.

operatingHours.description:
The Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail can be visited in any season.
It includes sections of walkable pathway, a Commemorative Motor Route, affiliated historic sites and museums, and wayside exhibits.
Along the way it passes through four NPS areas, two National Forests, an Army Corps of Engineers Dam &Reservoir, plus several state and county parks.
operatingHours.name: Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail

images.title: AlexandersFordAtTheGreenRiver
images.altText: The OVVI NHT marker is on a fence with the Green River in the background.
images.caption: A trail marker is on a fence with the Green River in the background.

images.title: Alexander's Ford Trail
images.altText: Reenactors march along the historic trail at Alexander's Ford in North Carolina.
images.caption: Reenactors march along the historic trail at Alexander's Ford in North Carolina.

images.title: Sign at Elkin Trail
images.altText: A sign on the Overmountain Victory Trail at Elkin reminds visitors not to stray off the trail.
images.caption: A sign on the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail at Elkin reminds visitors not to stray off the trail.

images.title: Compliant Trail Sign
images.altText: A sign on the trail indicates that this section is compliant with the American with Disabilitie Act.
images.caption: A sign on the trail indicates that this section is compliant with the American with Disabilitie Act.

images.title: Trail at Abingdon
images.altText: A marker stands beside the winding trail in Abingdon, Virginia.
images.caption: A marker stands beside the winding trail in Abingdon, Virginia.

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.
data.name: Overmountain Victory

data.fullName: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
data.description: Remember and commemorate the survival of the Cherokee people, forcefully removed from their homelands in Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee to live in Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. They traveled by foot, horse, wagon, or steamboat in 1838-1839.

entranceFees.description: There are NO USER OR ENTRY FEES fees for the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail. NOMINAL FEES may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please visit Plan Your Visit / Places To Go for an interactive map and extensive list of places to visit by state. Contact information is available for each site to call and find out about fees.
entranceFees.title: General Entrance Fee Information

data.directionsInfo: You can visit many of the sites along the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail over the 2,200+ mile route that crosses 9 states.

operatingHours.description: OPERATING HOURS VARY FROM SITE TO SITE. There are many historic sites, museums, and parks (federal, state, and local) along the Trail of Tears in Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Illinois, Arkansas, Missouri, or Oklahoma for you to visit. Please contact individual sites for more information by going to Plan Your Visit and selecting Places To Go or Passport Program, where sites are listed by state, and there is an interactive map to search for sites.
operatingHours.name: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail
Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

images.title: Chieftain's Museum, Rome, Georgia
images.altText: large white house, green lawn, two trees in front
images.caption: The museum tells the story of Major Ridge, the influential Ridge family including prominent son John Ridge, Cherokee history, and the Trail of Tears, as well as subsequent history of the home and region.

images.title: Brown's Ferry Tavern, Chattanooga, Tennessee
images.altText: structure in the background with large chimney on the end; signs saying Brown's Ferry Tavern
images.caption: Cherokee leader John Brown, who owned 640 acres in this area, ordered the construction of Browns Ferry Tavern in 1803. In 1838, the road running past this structure was the route by which several Cherokee detachments were removed to present-day Oklahoma.

images.title: Mantle Rock Preserve, Joy, Kentucky
images.altText: sunlight coming through trees with green leaves
images.caption: Thousands of Cherokee camped for weeks along the main (northern) route, near Mantle Rock, during the winter of 1838-39 as they waited for ice conditions in the Ohio River to allow a safe crossing.

images.title: Cherokee Retracement at Pea Ridge National Military Park, Garfield, Arkansas
images.altText: dozens of people walk a section of the Trail of Tears, winter scene, trees with no leaves
images.caption: The Pea Ridge National Military Park encompasses 4,300 acres and features a visitor center, museum, self-guided tours, reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern, and a retracement trail along a 2.5-mile original route segment of the Trail of Tears.

images.title: Grave Stone of William Adair, Stilwell, Oklahoma
images.altText: gravestone with words etched, green grass
images.caption: When the Cherokee arrived at their prescribed disbandment depot in Oklahoma, settlements sprang up nearby. There was a depot at the Adair's farm near present-day Stilwell, Oklahoma.

images.title: Crabb Abbott Farm, Grantsburg, Illinois
images.altText: Two people walk a remnant of the Trail of Tears. Spring setting with green leafed trees.
images.caption: Crabb Abbott Farm has segments of the Northern Route, including the rock crossing and ford of Sugar Creek. These segments are contiguous with trail segments on the adjacent Shawnee National Forest.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: Trail Of Tears

data.description: Wind, sand, and a dream of flight brought Wilbur and Orville Wright to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina where, after four years of scientific experimentation, they achieved the first successful airplane flights on December 17, 1903. With courage and perseverance, these self-taught engineers relied on teamwork and application of the scientific process. What they achieved changed our world forever.

entranceFees.description: The fee allows entrance to Wright Brothers National Memorial for one person, 16 years old or older, for seven consecutive days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Adult

entranceFees.description: Free admission to Wright Brothers National Memorial for any person 15 years old and younger.
entranceFees.title: Children

entranceFees.description: For commercial vehicles with seating capacity of 1-6 passengers, the cost is $25 + $7/person. Federal passes are not applicable for commercial tour fees.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Sedan

entranceFees.description: For commercial van or small bus with seating capacity of 7-25 passengers. Federal passes are not applicable for commercial tour fees.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Van/Small Bus

entranceFees.description: For commercial motorcoach with seating capacity of 26+ passengers. Federal passes are not applicable for commercial tour fees.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Motorcoach

entrancePasses.description: The annual pass (available for purchase at the entrance station) allows unlimited entry to Wright Brothers National Memorial for 12 months from date of purchase. Pass admits the passholder(s) + 3 adults (16 years of age and older).
entrancePasses.title: Wright Brothers Annual Pass

data.directionsInfo: Wright Brothers National Memorial is located along US 158 in the town of Kill Devil Hills on the Outer Banks of North Carolina.

operatingHours.description: These are the times the park grounds and visitor center are open for visitors.
operatingHours.name: Hours of Operation

images.credit: Wilbur Wright, Orville Wright, and John Daniels
images.title: First Flight
images.altText: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time as Wilbur assists.
images.caption: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time on December 17, 1903.

images.title: Busts and Moon
images.altText: Copper busts of the two brothers with the moon visible in the blue sky.
images.caption: Copper busts of Wilbur and Orville Wright stand atop Big Kill Devil Hill.

images.title: First Flight Boulder
images.altText: The large boulder and plaque sit where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.
images.caption: This boulder marks the spot where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.

images.title: Walking Along History
images.altText: Visitors walk along the flight line where Wilbur and Orville Wright flew and landed.
images.caption: Visitors explore the landing spots of the Wright brothers' first flights.

images.title: Wright Brothers Monument
images.altText: View straight up at the monument with the Sun directly behind the stonework.
images.caption: Black-and-white image of the Wright Brothers Monument

images.title: National Aviation Day
images.altText: Two young girls look across the grounds of Wright Brothers National Memorial.
images.caption: Visitors enjoy celebrating aviation where modern aviation was born.

images.title: Journey to the Top
images.altText: Visitors moving along a sidewalk to the top of the hill where the monument stands.
images.caption: Visitors climb Big Kill Devil Hill to visit the Wright Brothers Monument.

data.weatherInfo: Weather on the Outer Banks varies seasonally and daily. Summers can be very hot and sunny (wear sunscreen and drink water), while winters can be cold and wet. High winds are always a possibility any time of the year. It is not uncommon for a brief winter snow each year. Being on a barrier island, the memorial is susceptible to storm impacts, including hurricanes in the summer and nor'easters in the winter. No matter what time of year you visit, dress for the weather, and be ready for wind!
data.name: Wright Brothers
